body: Some of the neighbors had been heard to express the wish over the years that a divine hand would smite Yeung Sun Live Poultry. Clucking chickens went into its storefront. Dead ones came out, bound for Chinatown restaurants. So did blood, and entrails, and putrid odors that wafted past the fancy lofts and dark-wood bars of an up-and-coming
title: A Collapse At a Poultry Shop Exposes a Rift Among Neighbors

body: Prospect Park Audubon Center Some see the arrival of the new year as an excuse to act like animals. And on Sunday at least one place will even encourage it. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: IN a fancy women's department store in Osaka, Japan, earlier this year, shoppers lined up for one of the latest food fads in the country, jars of pickled herring. title: A Starring Role for the Little Humble Herring

body: TWO years ago, when David and Kathleen Conte moved to New York, they were relatively unfamiliar with it. Mr. Conte is from the Boston suburbs, and Ms. Conte is a native of Berlin, Germany. title: THE HUNT; Life Without Earplugs

title: Visions of a Development Rising From the Sea

Some are less well known, like solyanka, a soup served with smoked meats; a vodka-laced
title: Off the Menu

body: THE restaurant was Chinese in theory, with Continental accents, and wedged into a basement in Midtown. There was foie gras in the dumplings. The music was the sort one hears in elevators in cities far from home. One of my guests happened to be a dead ringer for the actor Matthew Broderick. ''I have waited on you many times,'' the waiter said to
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Pleasure to Dine With You

body: LIKE many restaurants, Saxon & Parole likes to tantalize a diner with an amuse-bouche. But at this new Bowery restaurant the waiter doesn't deliver a lightly grilled scallop or some tuna tartare on a slice of cucumber. No, he hands you a glass of vinegar. Well, not quite. Saxon & Parole's palate cleanser of choice is a shrub, which is not a leafy
title: Make Mine a Vinegar Solution

body: The scarlet letter may have little currency left in the realm of sexual indiscretion, but it continues to be put to vigorous use among parents -- the shaming impulse particularly thrives in the wealthier precincts of brownstone Brooklyn, where the exacting standards of urbane motherhood would seem to have been invented. title: BIG CITY; The Outcast of Brownstone Brooklyn

body: WHEN she and her husband moved out in 1980, Kathy LaPolla DeStefano was not at all happy with Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''The neighborhood was starting to go down the toilet, honestly,'' Ms. DeStefano, 56, an elementary school teacher, said over the telephone from her home in Coconut Creek, Fla. ''There was a lot of drugs and crime. It was an unsafe
title: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were

title: Mara Hoberman, Sam Schechner

body: Opening JUNG SIK The Korean flavors are unmistakable here but there are also touches of France and Spain in the cutting-edge cooking of Jung Sik Yim, who first took molecular, sous-vide and deconstructed Korean dishes to Seoul. New York will taste his bibim-style caprese salad, tiny octopus with kimchi and chicken in mushroom stock: 2 Harrison
title: Off the Menu

body: After the roar, after the first ground-trembling collapse sent clouds of pulverized matter billowing through Lower Manhattan, a man paused from his hurried retreat to take in a world now coated with the dust of uncertain gray. For reasons he still cannot explain, he bent down, scooped some of this grayness into an envelope -- and kept on moving.
title: THE 9/11 DECADE; What We Kept

body: IT'S a challenge for restaurants to offer exciting lists of expensive or even moderately expensive wines. It requires creativity, thoughtfulness and dedication to gather wines that may not return as big a profit as the more expensive choices on
title: THE POUR; Restaurant Bottles From the Bottom Up

body: DENNY SHEEHAN liked what he saw when he checked out the ground-floor one-bedroom in Cobble Hill on his lunch hour. The apartment, with a small extra room, was larger than others he had seen for a similar price, $2,050 a month. So, last summer, he and his girlfriend, Aimée Scala, moved in. From then on, they regretted it almost every day. The
title: THE HUNT; What? Can't Hear You! Let's Move

title: A New York Calm Amid the Storm

body: BRIAN WHITELEY loves his bicycle, a black fixed-gear Schwinn that he rides around New York City almost every day. Mr. Whiteley, an artist, and his wife, Mar Granados, an architect, are not permitted to take their bikes
title: The Bicycle Muscles In

body: As she and other customers picked the shelves bare on Friday afternoon at a supermarket in Breezy Point, Queens, Jackie Fede said she planned to abide by the official order to evacuate before Hurricane Irene hit. But she had yet to convince her mother to go. ''They're saying the ocean's going to meet the bay,'' said Ms. Fede, 25, a nursing student
title: Ordered Out, Some Residents Begin Retreat From Hurricane

body: ''Vitello tonnato is simple,'' Gherardo Guarducci was saying, talking over a mobile phone in his fast, Italian-flecked English from the dining room of Casa Lever, the elegant Manhattan restaurant of which he is an owner. The dish combines cold veal with a thick, creamy sauce flavored with canned or jarred tuna to make a meal of outrageous textural
title: EAT; Strangers on a Plate

body: Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn't resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss -- the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City -- and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you
title: CITY ROOM; A Heavy Nuisance Becomes a Sculptor's Niche

body: Stanley Bosworth, a self-described ''old wizard'' who shaped his own Hogwarts in Brooklyn in the form of Saint Ann's School, which rapidly gained national prominence for its free-form approach to education and its success in sending graduates to top colleges, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83. The cause was complications of
title: Stanley Bosworth, 83, Iconoclastic Head of Brooklyn School

body: Millerton, N.Y. FROM the venerable general store his grandparents opened in 1919, where you can get hunting knives, cigars, worms, khaki pants and copies of Vogue, Phil Terni has watched Dutchess County's passing parade for most of his 68 years. The store has seen celebrated customers -- Babe Ruth, Ava Gardner, Artie Shaw, Ruth Bader Ginsburg --
title: Williamsburg on the Hudson

title: So You Think You Can Judge Dance

body: WHEN a baby whale lost its way and wandered into the mouth of the Gowanus Canal in 2007, it was christened Sludgie the Whale. The name stuck. When Sludgie died after two days of rescue attempts, there was sadness but little surprise. Something from the natural world had found itself in one of the most unnatural places in the country. Over the
title: Gowanus: Big Development Can Wait

body: Dead of summer, but still the postman trudges forth to the mountaintop with questions for Mr. Critic, meditating on his zafu pillow. title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; New York at First Bite: Oh, the Places You'll Go

body: NOT all that long ago, rental prices were low enough for Jeni Aron to afford an alcove studio in a luxury doorman building, Hudson Crossing, on Ninth Avenue and 37th Street. She enjoyed a nicely furnished lobby, a landscaped patio, a storage room for her bicycle and a 24-hour gym that she used early in the morning. She had never before lived in a
title: THE HUNT; Time to Pull Up Stakes

body: The season's weather has had no effect on the efforts of the people who deliver the mail to Mr. Critic's garret on West 41st Street. There were questions this week from people celebrating marriages and those who might be doing so soon, as well as from visitors from afar. You may as ever send your inquiries about where to eat in New York City to me
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; Romance With No Recipe

body: When Ed and Paula Antonio moved from a small home in Marine Park, Brooklyn, to a roughly 3,000-square-foot house in Belle Harbor, Queens, they realized that with all that space and a central air-conditioning system, their electricity costs would run much higher. So after intensive research and analysis and the bids of five contractors, they paid
title: THE APPRAISAL; Solar Panels Still Rare, Despite Glow of $7 Power Bills

title: For Soda, The Genie Is Out of The Bottle

title: All Charges Are Dropped In an Attack In Brooklyn

title: FOOD STUFF; Croissants and Confit, With Cured Fish Down the Street

body: AS the real estate market in New York City shuffles toward recovery, two-bedroom apartments have been the last to rejoin the party. title: 2-Bedrooms Are Back

title: You're Never Too Old to Learn Shoemaking

body: THE lack of good restaurants in Brooklyn Heights has been a topic of discussion along the neighborhood's leafy sidewalks at least since the first white-shoe lawyers crossed the Brooklyn Bridge to settle there. title: RESTAURANTS; At Home in the Neighborhood

title: HABITATS | CARROLL GARDENS, BROOKLYN; The Reconstituted Row House

title: A Voice Where Romance And Dysfunction Meet

title: DANCE REVIEW; A Boozy Word Slinger and His Obscure Objects of Desire

body: EVER since her first visit three decades ago, New York is where Lynn Gall wanted to live. ''I remember being incredibly energized,'' she said, ''and I thought, 'This is where things happen.' It was so different from any other place I had ever been.'' She and her husband, Robert, who both come from the Midwest, visited occasionally from their home
title: THE HUNT; A Base Camp for Urban Exploration

body: Everyone knows that some of the best people-watching in New York City can be had in Hell's Hundred Acres. title: ProCro, SoBro, FiDi, BoCoCa: A Lawmaker Says, 'Enough'

body: HAVING lived primarily in postwar high-rises, Jordan Kingston envisioned a charming brownstone as her next home. But, after a few weeks of apartment-hunting, she and her husband, Michael, discovered that
title: THE HUNT; 'Something New and Sparkly'

body: The police have revised the account of a Friday fight between the owner of a popular Brooklyn pizzeria and a man whom a senior law enforcement official described as a Genovese mob associate, after finding witnesses who said that both men had wielded knives. The police were investigating whether the encounter had arisen out of a mob attempt to make
title: Mob Link Is Pursued in Fight Involving Owner of Pizzeria

title: Man Stabs Restaurateur In Brooklyn, Police Say

title: In Brooklyn, Cruise Ships Will Plug In To End Fumes

title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Sweet on Tiki, The Flower of Cocktails

body: I used to love eating out; I don't anymore. Even though the smokers have been moved outside and the food is more likely to be from some local, free-range, organic farm, and I can finally afford the ''better'' places, I would rather stay home - because I am tired of the noise. I arrived at this conclusion after a particularly ear-splitting week. I
title: COMPLAINT BOX | SHUSH!; Restaurants Should Adopt a Diet of Quiet

A casual menu of sandwiches, antipasti and plated dishes is planned throughout the day and evening. ''There won't just be Parmesan things,'' Mr. Carbone
title: Off the Menu

body: Fresh Direct started selling groceries online in New York City nine years ago, and in that time, one of its biggest national competitors, Peapod, has circled ever closer to Manhattan. But it has not crossed the river -- until now. Starting on Sunday, armed with a hefty budget for parking tickets, Peapod plans to roll its delivery trucks through big
title: Online Rival Rolling Out New Weapon In Grocery War

body: Cayuga Pure Organics near Ithaca, N.Y., has been one of the leaders of the local grain movement. It is also selling breads made with their grains that are baked by Orwasher's bakery on the Upper East Side. A round whole-grain bread was the first, and Cayuga has added a longer loaf, with a braided pattern on top, called Otis Stout Bread. It is made
title: FOOD STUFF; Otis Stout Bread Makes Its Debut

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: MANY gifted cooks have a vivid memory of their first experience in the kitchen. For Marisa Robertson-Textor, a 36-year-old freelance writer who grew up in the Bay Area of California, that memory involves making dinner for her family when she was 6. ''It was some riff on tacos, my favorite meal,'' she recalled. ''Preformed packaged tacos, as best I
title: HABITATS | FORT GREENE, BROOKLYN; Oh, the Dinners She Has Known

body: STEPHEN ANTONSON, an artist with a wily and mischievous point of view, is fond of saying that when he makes something, he'd like that thing to do more than just lie there. He might throw in a sight gag: a plaster bust of Pan wears a cream pie in his face; a ghostly plaster side table erupts into a fruit bowl. Or maybe he'll set up a word pun. Home
title: ON LOCATION; Making It Up As They Go

body: Water flecked with Brooklyn dirt trickled down on Tom O'Brien's hard hat from the arched ceiling of the Gowanus Canal flushing tunnel. Fifty-five feet underground, it made for a funny kind of rain. Each drop began as snow on Degraw Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, seeping slowly through sand and earth before wending its way through the tunnel's
title: Tenaciously Foul, And Getting A Good Flush

body: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor's Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: BAMKIDS FILM FESTIVAL Where do you take a 2- or 3-year-old to see movies? Most parents would probably say you don't. But every February at least one group of theaters welcomes filmgoers who are as new to motion pictures as they are to walking and talking. That's the BAM Rose Cinemas at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, host of the BAMkids Film
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: A yearlong investigation of the Gowanus Canal in preparation for its cleanup under the federal Superfund program has confirmed the severe extent of its contamination and the threat it poses to public health, particularly for people who eat fish from it or have repeated contact with its water or sediment. title: Gowanus Canal Tests Show Severity of Contamination

author: Andrew Cotto is a writer who lives in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and teaches in Downtown Brooklyn.
body: As a student and a teacher of language, I appreciate curses and other vulgarities: they can add color and emphasis to our vernacular. But like all stylistic flourishes, the audience has to be taken into consideration. So here's the current quandary. The distinction between where it is and is not appropriate to curse - and I am not just talking
title: COMPLAINT BOX | OBSCENITIES; Any Profanity-Free Zones Left on the Planet?

body: In the late 19th century, a cluster of buildings along or near Park Row, close to those busy news engines, City Hall and the city's courts, housed almost every daily newspaper in town -- The Herald, The Sun, The Tribune, The World, The Journal and The Times. title: LOWER MANHATTAN JOURNAL; Near Newspaper Row Of Years Gone By, The Media Return

title: LIVING ON | FOURTH AVENUE, BROOKLYN; New Cityscape, in Search of Green Space

body: MICHAEL MOSHAN bought his first condo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 2003. A few years later he persuaded his girlfriend, Shana Liebman, to move there from the West Village. title: Williamsburg, Toddlertown

body: A listing in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday referred incorrectly to the restaurant Calexico in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. title: CORRECTIONS

title: Off the Menu

title: Newbery Awarded To Debut Author
